the problem is, what you are describing happens *by default* under Ubuntu Edgy and later, since upstart is the *default* initializer
ok, thanks.  I didn't know.

if you want to try to improve startup time a little, and you are *already* under edgy, reboot, then at the GRUB prompt, hit "e", go to the kernel line, hit "e", add the word " profile", then hit "b" to boot

startup will take much longer than usual, which means the system is analyzing startup files in order to optimize the loading sequence
then, next time you boot it should be slightly faster
